disgust.translation[0].definitions[0].de: a strong feeling of dislike, annoyance, or disapproval
disgust.translation[0].definitions[0].ex: Joan looked at him with disgust.
Sam threw his books down in disgust and stormed out of the room.
Much to my disgust, I found that there were no toilets for the disabled.
The fans didn’t hide their disgust at the umpire’s decision.
disgust.translation[0].definitions[1].de: a very strong feeling of dislike that almost makes you sick, caused by something unpleasant
disgust.translation[0].definitions[1].ex: He reached into the bin with a look of disgust on his face.
Edward tasted the thin, sour wines with disgust.
disgust.translation[1].definitions[0].de: to make someone feel very annoyed or upset about something that is not acceptable
disgust.translation[1].definitions[0].ex: Many parents claimed to be disgusted by the amount of violence in the film.
Dear Sir, I was disgusted to see the picture on page one of Sunday’s feature section.
It disgusts me that he got away with it.
disgust.translation[1].definitions[1].de: to be so unpleasant that it makes you feel almost sick
disgust.translation[1].definitions[1].ex: The thought of eating insects disgusts me.
